results.title: subscape_PROOF
results.brief_description:
Traditionally, western cartography combines multiple data sets in a two dimensional representation. The datamapping (cross-referencing of datasets) tells a story - the land use and landforms of a place. Imaginative and politicised choice of datasets creates more esoteric ‘maps’.

sub_scapePROOF uses video/audio footage of televised political rhetoric and confessional TV shows. Onto these are mapped other sources of ‘data’ generated from philosophical and poetic texts.

sub_scapePROOF critiques the notion of evidential, superficial ‘truth’, in a post-faith age. By mapping data from post-colonial locations back onto the language of superpower politics, sub_scape generates a playful and ironic critique on the traditional politics and power dynamics of knowledge-through-mapping.
- Waterson and Richards.

results.title: Evidence
results.creator_credit: Claire Pentecost, Critical Art Ensemble, Igor Vamos and Steve Kurtz
results.brief_description: Video evidence of the FBI raid of Professor Steve Kurtz’s home which led to his being charged with bio terrorism. The video has a voice over relating the history of events, and shows the aftermath of the FBI raids. This video was created specifically for the exhibition PROOF held in the ACMI screen gallery December 2004.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Claire Pentecost, Critical Art Ensemble, Igor Vamos and Steve Kurtz

results.title: Greetings From Iraq
results.brief_description:
I was born in 1962 in a village on the Euphrates River near Najaf in Iraq. In 1985, I graduated with a degree in applied theatre studies from the Institute of Fine Arts in Baghdad. Shortly after completing my studies I went into exile in northern Iraq: I was waiting for political change to go back home. After crossing the border from Iraq to Iran, I was arrested, imprisoned and transferred to a detention centre. I remained there for seven weeks before I was transferred to another detention centre in Tehran. I was there for 11 months.
In the detention centre there was the constant threat of being deported back to Iraq. I got a false passport and was travelling to Syria when I was arrested again for having false papers.
I escaped to the Pakistan-Iran border; I introduced myself to UNHCR (United Nations High Commission for Refugees) as an Iraqi refugee. I spent - or wasted - seven years of my life waiting for an answer from the UNHCR regarding my application for resettlement.
I was finally accepted as a refugee by Australia. In 1997, I arrived in Perth. In 2001, I became an Australian citizen. In 2003, I finished my Master of Creative Arts at Newcastle University.
In 2004, I want back to see my homeland for the first time after 17 to 18 years in exile, afterwards returning to Australia.
- Niz Jabour

Taken from PROOF exhibition 2004

results.title: Obstruction
results.brief_description:
Compiling short video sequences from documentary filmmakers, journalists and video activists including Peter Vaughan, John Flynn, Pip Starr, Russell Hawkins, Kim Beamish, John Hughes, Izzy, SKA TV and Paul O’Connor
(Undercurrents), Riley highlights the potential hazards of their work. Obstruction details the physical frustration involved in gathering evidence: the intervention of law enforcement and figures of authority or the recurring use of the hand to cover the camera’s lens, thereby obscuring our vision.

The staccato bursts of movement and blurred point-of-view in Obstruction challenge the notion of a centralised, transcendent eye/I behind the camera. Riley’s camera is a witness to the ways in which evidence is mediated and subject to the whim of external forces outside the filmmaker’s control. All the media artists featured in Obstruction have experienced physical disruptions in their search for proof. Prevented from continuing to record particular events and activities, Riley questions whether the public’s right-to-know is overruled by the right to privacy on behalf of the individual or corporation.
